metadata.name: CSS Crystals‚ú® #146
metadata.description:
This 3D HTML + CSS based work utilizes only a limited amount of javascript to construct the scene and facilitate interactive controls. üö´ <canvas>! Continuing the collab with my alternate identity HTMLCSS.TEZ

The practice of layering many graphic shapes and gradients with a chaotic mix of blending modes has been with me since my first years of photoshop in my youth. It's a familiar, friendly technique. Yet, I've rarely played with it outside photoshop. Here I take the opportunity to apply this abstract blending technique in a manner that alludes to reality: refracting crystals.

These generated crystals are not based in fact but imagination. They are illustrative of the magic and wonder some people associate with real life minerals and rocks. They blend together with impossible color changes only possible in the virtual.

Each individual crystal element can be one of these blend modes (with chance):
difference (9/16), exclusion (2/16), hard-light (2/16), color-dodge (1/16), overlay (1/16), normal (1/16)

Controls:
Play/Pause - [Space]
Rotate - [Click + Drag]
Move - [Shit + Click + Drag]

Minter's Reward: 1/3 Secondary royalties

metadata.name: Peruvian Cloth #128
metadata.description:
Peruvian Cloth attempts to realistically capture the texture and feel, the patterns and colours of ............. Cloth from Peru. 

You are invited to render it large to see the digital fabrication of the fabric. 
Use keys 1-6 to render at increasing resolutions and 0 to render at window size.

metadata.name: Fourier Series  #180
metadata.description: Fourier Series experiment.

metadata.name: Rain #182
metadata.description:
#fxhashturnsone
Here comes the rain.

An abstract piece, celebrating all the moods and emotions that, life-giving, rain brings.
Spring Showers, brooding storms and torrents.
Reflected within us all.

Primary split 20% to Save Pakistan 20% Processing Foundation.

Made with p5js and love.
Mac

L to download 825x1169
S to download 1754x2480
H to download 3508x4960 < This may/will break.

metadata.name: Annum #8344
metadata.description:
This project is being released in celebration of the 1 year aniversary of Achromat, my first release on fxhash. In addition to being inspired by Achromat, aspects of other previous projects have been incorporated. My deepest gratitude to all who have collected my work over the past year.

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

50% of primary sales go to Savepakistan.

metadata.name: Nexum #163
metadata.description:
Happy birthday fx(hash)! A piece dedicated to the #fxhashturnsone event!

50% of proceeds go towards the Processing foundation.

Press S to save a .png version of your token.

metadata.name: CSS Molecules #85
metadata.description:
This 3d animated work is composed almost completely of HTML + CSS. There is a limited amount of javascript to construct the scene and facilitate interactive controls. üö´ <canvas>!

A bit of history about this approach: As my first coding language HTML and CSS holds a special place in my heart. Even when I jumped into 3D my first creations were made with just some html + css coded in notepad. Earlier this year I took this idea to the next level with a yet-to-be-released 3D bedrooms project, filling it with objects and ever-refining my scene construction practice. This system for scene construction became the basis for a few other generative projects here on fxhash under my pseudonym htmlcss.tez. Here I abandon my usual representational focus with this technique and dive right into the abstract.

metadata.name: Ataraxis #431
metadata.description:
Ataraxis (or a broken volume renderer) is an exploration in balancing discomfort and calm. The piece generates spaces on the fly that are designed to elicit strange and uncomfortable feelings - like a desolate, alien dreamscape - claustrophobic, surreal, not quite real yet strangely recognisable. But the idea is that while these spaces feel uncomfortable, they're also strangely, antilogically calming. The idea is to elicit a sanguine emotion, to make the viewer feel calm in a strange place, and to lead them somewhere else.

This work is the culmination of many years of work researching volumetric rendering techniques. This token uses a raymarching technique that is intentionally broken in various ways.

Controls:
Double-click to download
&w=X&h=y to change the size of the piece
&dpr=x to change the resolution of the pice - higher resolutions will result in slightly different artworks as the browser attempts to compensate for the overlarge canvas
&fullscreen=true to change the token to display the full size of your browser. This may impact the rendering of the token, so use with caution

metadata.name: Abacus I #16
metadata.description:
Abacus I is my contribution to celebrating #fxhashturnsone.

This collection combines features and code from my previous fx(hash) projects.

50% of primary sales are donated to Processing Foundation.

metadata.name: P√¢tisserie #320
metadata.description:
happy birthday fx(hash)!

/////
key "1" - "9": increases the render resolution by 2x with each step
-> These will automatically export a png after the simulation is done.
(Alternatively, you can contact me on Twitter and i can render a high res file in the size you need).

metadata.name: Caught in the maelstrom #116
metadata.description:
An ever-growing vortex consisting of lots of different mesh lines that move in unison.

Clicking the canvas will trigger a boost in speed and line size, and produce a random chord by the main synth.

Holding down your pointer will reverse the vortex and play an additional synth on release. Double tapping will have the same effect audio-wise.

This is part of the celebration of fxhash turning 1. That‚Äôs why there are 365 editions, and 50% of all primary sales will be donated evenly between ‚ÄúProcessing Foundation‚Äù and ‚ÄúThree.js‚Äù. 20% of all royalties are given back to the minter.

Here are some stats for you:

About 1/10 will render the lines in wireframes.
There are 2 different synth pitches distributed evenly.
10% will have one single line color, instead of 3 primary ones.
In rough measures, every 4th will have an irregular wiggle motion flow instead of a circular one.

In addition to all of the above, there can be different values in regards to line counts, line lengths, line widths, speeds, width grows, radius increments, angle increments, z-index increments, background colors, border colors, and so on.

#fxhashturnsone

@computeremotions - 2022-11-13

metadata.name: (un)connected #60
metadata.description:
A playful collection for #fxhashturnsone.

(un)connected
the older we get,
the more we risk losing the connection,
with who we once were,
what we still are,
colorful,
loving and caring,
playful,
connected

be
childlike


Thank you very much for this amazing first year. 


Controls:

- Press [p] to save the current image
- Press [1-5] to render and save the image in a higher resolution (1 = low; 5 = high)

Made with p5. All primary sales go to Savepakistan. Royalties go to the Processing Foundation.

Tested with Safari Version 16.1 (18614.2.9.1.12) and Chrome Version 107.0.5304.87. Browser updates can affect the future behavior.

metadata.name: Azulejo #219
metadata.description:
Azulejo is a generative work made with p5.js

Behind this artwork, the author (eduxdux) had made a lot of research about tiling, the main references for this work were Athos Bulc√£o, Alexandre Mancini, and "Azulejo da igrejinha" by C√¢ndido Portinari.

This artwork has 8 color palettes and 7 tile styles.
If you have lucky you can have a fully filled tile.

This work is participating in the FxHash anniversary event (#fxhashturnsone) and 10% of the royalties go to the Save Pakistan

Eduxdux November 2022

metadata.name: Lost in the attraction / abstraction #179
metadata.description:
This project is an experiment with a chaotic attractor, radial symmetry and some Perlin noise.

---
Features

Parts: the number of symmetrical parts (4|6|8|10)

Palette: the palette chosen to draw the sketch

Attractors incrementation: a number between 0.0013 and 0.003 which will increment the parameters (a, b, c & d) of an attractor (Clifford A. Pickover).

---
Resolutions & controls

By default the work is drawn on a canvas of 1280 x 1280 pixels but you can double or triple this resolution, for this in live mode add to the URL &scale= with the desired factor.

You can also download an image (PNG) by pressing [d] key.


---
This artwork celebrate the first anniversary of FxHash, 50% of the proceeds will go to the Processing Foundation.


Created with typescript and simplex-noise (npm package). 

Artwork by Nicolas Lebrun / @nclslbn / https://nicolas-lebrun.fr/contact/

metadata.name: √∞olmen #148
metadata.description:
√∞olmen is a generative art project by Diego Pintos.
It draws rectangles with points instead a plain color or border. With some variations in the distribution of this points, we get a kind of noise depth effect.

12 carefully selected palettes. Based in Art Masterpieces and in Nature.
¬∑ Gioconda (Leonardo da Vinci)
¬∑ Guernika (Pablo Picasso)
¬∑ Nighthawks (Edward Hopper)
¬∑ Meninas (Diego Velazquez)
¬∑ Judith beheading Holofernes (Caravaggio)
¬∑ Al Siq (nature)
¬∑ guacamayo (nature)
¬∑ Salamanca (nature)
¬∑ mostaza (nature)
¬∑ Timanfaya (nature)
¬∑ piedra (nature)
¬∑ firefall (nature)

√∞olmen builds 10 compositions:
¬∑ Square
¬∑ PersonChen's Style
¬∑ Equilibrium
¬∑ Hanging
¬∑ Pyramid
¬∑ Row
¬∑ Column
¬∑ 3 columns (randomly aligned)
¬∑ 3 rows (randomly aligned)
¬∑ Frame

Density
¬∑ Tiny: Less than 35 rects. Rare
¬∑ Small: Less than 100 rects. Common.
¬∑ Medium: Less than 250 rects. Common.
¬∑ High: Less than 350 rects. Common.
¬∑ Massive: Less than 500 rects. Rare.
¬∑ Ultra: More than 500 rects. Rarest.

Rarities
¬∑ Rectangle filling type: Filled (95%) or unfilled (5%)
¬∑ Monochrome: Just black and white. Always unfilled. (1%)
¬∑ Dark mode: Dark background (20%). Dark mode can be monochrome.
¬∑ Habitable (90%). See humans later.

Humans
√∞olmen can host tiny humans. Contains a little code that draws humans looking down, in order to to provide size perspective.

Minting
Each √∞olmen contains all rarities inside. As a √∞olmen collector, you can display your final piece in all available formats, and rarity owners can display the regular filled composition. In addition, this can help if you want to print one or more formats.

Tricks and Keys
√∞olmen is responsive, you can zoom out your browser window and refresh to get a larger output.
's' save the current canvas
'd' toggle dark mode
'f' toggle fill mode
'm' toggle monochrome

More info and visual description:
https://thelirios.com/dolmen/

Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Spirali #49
metadata.description:
INSPIRATION

Spirali was inspired by Tyler Hobbs' work with flow fields. However, instead of selecting random starting points for each shape to be drawn, which is more usual in flow fields works, I wanted to constrain the starting points to certain positions so that the shape being drawn could expand freely without the risk of colliding with other shapes, that's when I got to the spiral flow field.

WHY SPIRALI?

The name of this collection is not only a direct translation of spirals in Italian, but it is also related to Italian cuisine and my own personal experience in Italy. The relationship with Italian cuisine is due to the immense number of types of pasta that exist, including one called spirali. When I was a child I only knew three or four types of pasta, but when I became a bit older I was amazed to learn that there were many more. Actually, there are hundreds. Just like from the same type of basic dough, you can make hundreds of types of pasta, my idea was, from just one type of spiral flow field, to make hundreds of images. A strategy of forcing creativity by imposing a major constraint.

The name of this collection also relates to my personal experience because it was visiting Italy many years ago that I first became interested in art and design because of the beautiful buildings, churches and works of art that I came across.

DESIGN STRATEGY

A spirali is made up of several tails and each tail is made up of a basic element, which I called slice. A tail may have from one to thousands slices. It is mainly the variation in the number of slices and how they are colored that creates the different tail styles in each spirali.

The slices start at the center of the spiral and in each iteration they grow a certain length or split in two depending on the parameters used in the algorithm, which also determine the outline and fill of each slice when it is rendered.

FEATURES

The main features that a spirali can have are:

- Styles: Refers to the drawing patterns of each tail, that means, the shape, fill and stroke of the slices that form the tail. There are about 16 possible styles from which the algorithm will choose about 3 for each spirali.

- Zoom out: It is related to how much larger the flow field area is in comparison to the image area. There are two possibilities: 50% and 100%.

- Curvature: An arbitrary measure of the rate the tails of a spirali are turning. A spirali can have high or low curvature.

- Rotation: The rotation direction: clockwise or counterclockwise.

- Tails: The number of tails in a spirali.

- Palette: The palette's name. There are about 14 possible palettes.

COMMANDS:

- Press "m" to export a medium resolution image (2000px x 2000px);
- Press "h" to export a high resolution image (6000px x 6000px);

LICENSING

Please see license.txt file.

Twitter: @PauloSilvaGArt
Site: https://paulosilva.art
